I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   During the country programming  mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
January  2008,  the  Government  of  Nepal  requested  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to 
strengthen the capacity of the Public Procurement Monitoring Office (PPMO). ADB granted the 
Government’s request and included the TA in its country operations business plan for 2008.1  A 
TA fact-finding mission was fielded from 29 May to 6 June 2008. A wrap-up meeting was held 
on 6 June 2008, chaired by the joint secretary of the Ministry of Finance. The mission agreed 
with the Government on the purpose, outputs, methodology, key activities, costs and financing 
plan, implementation arrangements, and scope of counterpart support.2  The TA design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since  the  end  of  the  decade-long  conflict  and  the  signing  of  the  peace  accord  in 
November  2006,  there  has  been  huge  demand  from  the  people  for  quick  delivery  of 
development results from the Government. It is important that the people’s aspirations are met 
for the peace and prosperity of the country, and that the development results are visible on the 
ground. Hence, the Government has embarked on major development projects that require 
transparency, accountability, economy, and efficiency. Good governance is one of the major 
pillars in the Government’s 3-year interim plan (2008–2010).3  The Government is committed to 
obtaining maximum value from public expenditure through an improved public procurement 
system. Experience in other countries has shown that a sound public procurement system has 
contributed to 15% savings in public expenditure. In Nepal, where government procurement 
comprises  about  15%  of  gross  domestic  product,  such  savings  would  boost  the  budget 
significantly and could be utilized to help meet the Millennium Development Goals by 2015.  
 
3.  The Government—together with ADB, Department for International Development of the 
United Kingdom, Japan Bank for International Cooperation, and World Bank—conducted a joint 
country portfolio review mission in September 2006. The mission identified three major themes 
as pivotal factors to improve project implementation and enhance portfolio performance in Nepal: 
(i) financial  management,  (ii)  results-based  reporting,  and  (iii)  procurement  management. 
Subsequently, the Government promulgated the Public Procurement Act (PPA) in January 2007 
and approved the Public Procurement Regulations (PPR) in August 2007. These initiatives have 
been an important step in reforming the procurement system—thereby establishing the basic 
principles of procurement of transparency, open and fair competition, economy, and efficiency.  
 
4.  More  importantly,  the  Government  established  PPMO  in  August  2007  as  a  central 
agency responsible for developing and sustaining a well-functioning public procurement system. 
PPMO is headed by a secretary and has 18 full-time staff. The major activities initiated by 
PPMO so far are (i) briefing of the PPA and PPR to all secretaries of line ministries; (ii) selection 
of members for the procurement review committee; (iii) training on procurement at the regional 
and center level; (iv) establishment of procedures on debarment hearings; (v) networking for 
establishing a website; and (vi) support to all procuring entities. 
 
5.  A joint workshop organized by the Government, ADB, and World Bank in May 2007 
concluded that there is an urgent need for TA to support PPMO for effective implementation of

the  PPA  and  PPR.  The  workshop  identified  five  major  areas  of  support:  (i)  establish  a 
procurement system; (ii) build capacity of PPMO; (iii) create a public procurement monitoring 
system; (iv) produce standard bidding documents for works, goods, consulting services, and 
other services; and (v) explore e-procurement. The Government requested ADB assistance for 
capacity building of PPMO and knowledge sharing, so that an effective and efficient national 
procurement  institution  could  be  developed.  Knowledge  transfer  for  public  procurement  is 
crucial  for  the  Government  to  accelerate  development  efforts  and  improve  project 
implementation. Strengthening PPMO through TA is envisaged to play a vital role. 
 
6.  The TA will be financed by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership 
Fund, which aims to contribute to poverty reduction and economic and social development in 
ADB’s developing member countries. The major objectives of the fund are to (i) strengthen the 
capacity of developing member countries to achieve the Millennium Development Goals; (ii) 
promote information and communication technology; and (iii) bridge the digital divide, through 
national and regional e-strategies. The TA concept paper was reviewed by the e-Asia and 
Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  review  committee, 4  and  submitted  for  funding  from  the 
Government of the Republic of Korea, Funding for the TA was approved on 11 April 2008.  
 
7.    Improving transparency in public procurement proceedings, strengthening the capacity 
of  procuring  agencies,  and  institutional  development  of  anticorruption  institutions  are  an 
operational priority for instilling good governance that was identified as one of the three pillars of 
the  2005–2009  country  strategy  and  program  for  Nepal. 5  The  TA  is  conceptually, 
programmatically,  and  procedurally  aligned  with  the  country  strategy  and  program.  It  will 
address  the  policy,  institutional,  and  information  technology  aspects  of  procurement.  A 
strengthened  PPMO  could  facilitate  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  and  economic 
development targets through more efficient and effective public procurement.  
 
8.    The World Bank supports the initiative to strengthen PPMO and will establish an e-
procurement  system.  It  is  also  processing  TA  for  preparing  a  procurement  business  plan, 
developing  an  awareness  and  disseminating  strategy,  supporting  exposure  visits  to  other 
countries,  and  conducting  procurement  training  at  regional  and  zonal  levels  for  core 
implementation of the PPA and PPR. Both TA projects from the World Bank and ADB will 
address the immediate needs of PPMO without any duplication in the areas of assistance.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA impact is to improve the efficiency and transparency in public procurement of 
works,  goods,  and  services  to  promote  good  governance.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  is 
strengthened procurement capacity of the Government. 
 
10.  The outputs of the TA are (i) publication of standard bidding documents and public works 
directives; (ii) monitoring and evaluation unit strengthened; (iii) procurement website established; 
(iv) training module developed; (v) norms for debarment developed; and (vi) e-procurement 
strategy prepared.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented through extensive consultations with related stakeholders 
including government agencies, contractors, and consulting associations in Nepal. It will be 
implemented in close coordination with the World Bank and other development partners so that 
the Government’s procurement system can be harmonized and strengthened. It will include the 
activities summarized below. 
 
12.  Policy  Advice  and  Dialogue. A clear working policy with norms for  debarment of 
bidders,  consultants,  and  suppliers—on  the  grounds  of  corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  and 
coercive bidding practices—will be developed. The policy will also outline the guidelines for 
debarment when contractual obligations are not complied with during contract implementation. 
The norms will clearly spell out the debarment procedures to be followed by PPMO, from 
notification of procuring entities to final enforcement of debarment.  
       
13.  Capacity  Building  and  Institutional  Development.  The  TA  will  (i)  strengthen  the 
monitoring  and  evaluation  unit  of  PPMO  to  provide  proper  institutional  arrangements  for 
independent  review  of  public  procurement  proceedings  and  to  give  advice  on  effective 
implementation  of  the  PPA  and  PPR;  (ii)  develop  curriculum  and  training  modules  for 
procurement  training;  and  (iii)  train  PPMO  staff  on  the  United  Nations  Commission  on 
International  Trade  Law  model  of  arbitration  and  International  Federation  of  Consulting 
Engineers conditions of contracts. 
 
14.    Publications. The TA will support (i) preparation of standard bidding documents for 
procurement of works, goods, consulting, and other services in accordance with the PPA and 
PPR and standard forms for contracts and prequalification documents for mandatory use by all 
procuring  agencies  at  all  levels;  and  (ii)  review  of  the  existing  public  works  directives, 
instructions, technical notes, and manuals in line with the provisions of the PPA and PPR to 
ensure  that  public  procurement  procedures  are  uniformly  and  transparently  applied  by  all 
procurement practitioners. 
 
15.  Studies and Analytical Work. The TA will enhance the knowledge of PPMO staff on 
successful implementation of modern procurement legislation and best practices of relevant 
countries, including Republic of Korea, Malaysia, and Singapore through overseas study and 
observation.  
 
16.  Implementation of PPA and PPR. The TA will facilitate (i) full-fledged implementation 
of the PPA and PPR through operation of PPMO as an agent of reform during the entire TA 
period; and (ii) further reforms on procurement based on lessons from implementation of the 
PPA and PPR.  
 
17.  Networking  and  Dissemination.  A  PPMO  website  will  be  established  to  provide 
information on public procurement as mandated by the PPA. An e-procurement strategy will be 
developed  to  move  toward  full-fledged  e-procurement,  including  policy  and  legislative 
recommendations. The information on public procurement procedures will be disseminated 
through seminars and workshops.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated at $600,000 equivalent, of which the Government has requested 
ADB  to  finance  $500,000.  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  e-Asia  and

4   
Knowledge Partnership Fund, to be administered by ADB. The Government will finance the 
remaining $100,000 equivalent to cover the costs of counterpart staff, office accommodation 
and utilities, and office equipment. The Government has been informed that the approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing program. The details of the cost estimates are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the Executing Agency. PPMO, under the Office of the Prime Minister and 
Council of Ministers, will be the Implementing Agency. A TA coordination unit will be established 
under PPMO and will be headed by the TA director at the joint secretary (technical) level. The 
TA director will be responsible for day-to-day TA implementation and regularly report on the 
status of the TA to the secretary of PPMO as well as ADB. Two full-time PPMO staff with 
extensive knowledge on PPMO procurement will be assigned as the counterpart staff. The 
secretary of PPMO will provide overall guidance to the TA coordination unit and review all the 
TA outputs.  
 
20.  A steering committee will be formed, chaired by the secretary of PPMO. The members of 
the steering committee will be at the undersecretary level from the Ministry of Finance; Financial 
Comptroller General Office; Ministry of Physical Planning and Works; Ministry of Law, Justice 
and Parliamentary Affairs; and National Planning Commission. The steering committee will 
coordinate with the line ministries and provide overall guidance on policy initiatives undertaken 
by the TA. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, with the estimated start date of September 
2008  and  completion  target  of  August  2010.  The  detailed  implementation  schedule  is  in 
Appendix 3. Consultants for a total of 43 person-months will be recruited though a firm using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). One international e-procurement specialist 
(3  person-months)  and  eight  national  consultants  (total  input  of  38 person-months)  will  be 
engaged. The national specialists will be as follows: (i) institutional development specialist and 
team  leader,  (ii)  three  procurement  specialists,  (iii)  procurement  training  specialist, 
(iv) monitoring and evaluation specialist, (v) information technology specialist, and (vi) contract 
management  specialist.  There  is  provision  for  unallocated  national  consulting  inputs  of 
2 person-months, which will be utilized on an as-needed basis during TA implementation. The 
detailed  terms  of  reference  of  the  consultants  are  in  Appendix  4.  The  equipment  will  be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time) and will be handed over to PPMO after completion of the TA.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Nepal to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund for Knowledge Transfer for Public Procurement, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

10  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overall Outcome 
 
1.  The outcome of the technical assistance (TA) is strengthened procurement capacity of 
the Government to promote good governance. The major outputs will be standard bidding 
documents  prepared,  public  works  directives  updated,  manuals  updated,  training  modules 
developed, the evaluation and monitoring unit strengthened, a procurement website established, 
and norms developed for debarment. These are the key tools for the Public Procurement 
Monitoring Office (PPMO) to implement the Public Procurement Act (PPA), 2007, and Public 
Procurement Regulations (PPR), 2007. 
 
2.  The consultants will work closely with PPMO and associated departments to achieve the 
outputs  and  outcome.  The  consultants  will  ensure  effective  participatory  planning  when 
preparing relevant documents and will conduct stakeholders’ workshops before finalizing the 
documents and approval by PPMO. 
 
B.   Consulting Services Requirements 
 
3.  The TA will require a total of 43 person-months of consultant inputs: one international 
consultant  for  3  person-months,  eight  national  consultants  for  38  person-months,  and 
2 unallocated  person-months.  The  consultants  will  have  substantial  experience  relevant  to 
procurement, e-procurement, contract management, and capacity development.  
 
  1.  e-Procurement Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will develop a comprehensive strategy, including steps and guidelines, for 
introducing e-procurement in Nepal. The consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  In consultation with all stakeholders, review and define strategic goals for PPMO 
in terms of facilities, products, and customer service initiatives for development of 
e-procurement. 
(ii)  Assess the Government’s need for policy and regulation on e-procurement. 
(iii)  Review and analyze the current technology infrastructure and standards, and 
determine technology goals and standards that support the needs of the current 
processes,  as  well  as  the  infrastructure  requirements  for  e-procurement 
initiatives.  
(iv)  Develop a strategic plan for implementation of e-procurement. 
          
  2.  Team Leader and Institutional Development Specialist (national, 10 person-
months) 
 
5.   The  specialist  will  develop  a  comprehensive  organization  strategy  and  framework, 
including business plan, for institutional development of PPMO and effective TA management. 
Specific tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Liaison effectively with PPMO to deliver outputs and outcomes of the TA. 
(ii)  Undertake  a  review  and  develop  an  organization  strategy  for  institutional 
development of PPMO. 
(iii)  Develop  a  framework  and  business  plan  for  PPMO  so  that  a  transparent 
procurement system can be established.

(iv)  Assess and build the capacity of staff for undertaking and sustaining institutional 
development efforts. 
(v)  Coordinate and manage other consultants working for the TA so that the TA 
outcomes are achieved. 
(vi)  Prepare  monthly  and  quarterly  progress  reports  for  submission  to  ADB  and 
PPMO in a timely manner. 
(vii)  Coordinate with other consultants and government officials for preparation of the 
TA inception and completion reports. 
 
  3.  Procurement Specialists (3 national consultants, 4 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialists will prepare standard bidding documents for works, goods, consulting, 
and  other  services;  and  update  directives  and  manuals  for  procurement  of  works,  goods 
(including that of the health sector), consulting, and other services. Specific tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Review the PPA and PPR. 
(ii)  Prepare  standard  bidding  documents  for  works,  goods,  services,  and  other 
services in accordance with the PPA and PPR. 
(iii)  Examine the contract conditions of other development partners to develop a 
harmonized document.  
(iv)  Review and update existing public works directives, instructions, technical notes, 
and manuals.  
 
  4.   Procurement Training Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
7.  The  specialist  will  prepare  a  report  on  a  comprehensive learning  and  development 
strategy for capacity development of PPMO, and a curriculum and training module for training 
programs. Specific tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Assess and develop a comprehensive learning and development strategy for 
capacity development of PPMO. 
(ii)  Design and develop curriculum for PPMO staff and other related agencies. 
(iii)  Deliver training programs based on the curriculum developed. 
(iv)  Develop resource persons and trainers of trainees for future programs. 
(v)  Develop training modules and materials for all procurement-related activities, 
including debarment for trainers and trainees. 
(vi)  Develop criteria for accreditation and qualification of procurement staff in all 
procuring entities. 
 
  5.  Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
8.  The specialist will prepare a framework for establishing a results-based monitoring and 
evaluation system, including the cost estimates; and strengthen the monitoring and evaluation 
unit in PPMO. Specific tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Review PPMO’s organization structure and develop a framework for establishing 
a results-based monitoring and evaluation system. 
(ii)  Develop  reporting  arrangements  and  formats,  ensuring  effective  links  and 
coordination among stakeholders.

12  Appendix 4 
(iii)  Facilitate the establishment of a monitoring and evaluation system so that a 
proper  reporting  and  enforcing  mechanism  is  developed  for  procurement 
proceedings, implementation of procurement rules, and regulations and auditing.  
(iv)  Prepare  baseline  procurement  indicators,  including  public  expenditure  and 
financial accountability indicators. 
 
  6.  Information Technology Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
9.  The specialist will develop a PPMO website. Specific tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Review  and  analyze  PPMO’s  organization  structure  and  operation  for  the 
development of a website. 
(ii)  Establish  a  user-friendly  website  so  that  procurement-related  information  is 
accessed and disseminated effectively and efficiently. 
(iii)  Train related staff for continuous update and feedbacks. 
 
  7.  Contract Management Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
10.  The  specialist  will  develop  comprehensive  policies  and  procedures  for  contract 
administration. Specific tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Develop guidelines and procedures of contract administration. 
(ii)  Develop a manual related to arbitration procedure based on the model of the 
United Nations Commission on International Trade Law and dispute resolution 
procedures  in  the  International  Federation  of  Consulting  Engineers  and 
multilateral development bank contract conditions.  
(iii)  Develop norms and procedures for debarment of bidders, consultants, and 
suppliers when malpractice occurs during the procurement process.
